Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Evolution Equations on Singular Spaces; Luminy, France; April 25-29, 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "Evolution Equations on Singular Spaces," to be held at the Centre Internationale de Recontres Mathematiques in Luminy, France from April 25 to 29, 2016.

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the field of partial differential equations. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. The award gives early career researchers, researchers who are members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF a chance to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at:

http://scientific-events.weebly.com/1396.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award funded the travel of eight junior US participants to a meeting at CIRM in Luminy, France. The meeting focused on the behavior of waves in the presence of singularstructures, ranging from boundaries to corners, edges, cones, andcusps.  In these settings, the phenomenon of diffraction of waves is of central importance and considerable mathematical interest: in evolution equations such as the wave equation, for instance, wavefronts can be deflected by interactions with edges and corners in ways that go beyond the traditional “ray approximations” that in smooth geometries accurately describe the propagation.  These issues are both a theoretical obstruction to our good understanding of the estimates satisfied by classical and quantum waves, and also a difficulty in accurate computation, for instance in high frequency acoustical problems.  Among the pure mathematical problems discussed at the meeting were: Strichartz estimates for wave and Schrödinger equations in the presence of boundaries and corners; regularity of solutions to the wave equation in black hole backgrounds; bounds on solutions to Laplace and Helmholtz equations in domains with corners.  There were also talks on numerical analysis for the Helmholtz equation via hybrid asymptotic-numerical integral equation methods.

The meeting brought together researchers from a number of areas, including both elliptic and hyperbolic partial differential equations as well as applied mathematics and numerical analysis.  The interaction between the pure microlocal analysis community and the applied/numerical community seemed especially novel and successful.
